CARDINAL . The relevant LAW provides :

“ ... A citizen of GPE who has reached DATE on DATE of the elections has the right to vote and , if that citizen has resided on the territory of GPE for DATE , is eligible to be elected a member of parliament ... ”

CARDINAL . At the material time the NORP electoral system was governed by CARDINAL of this LAW . It was based on a mixed - member proportional system , where CARDINAL of the CARDINAL members of PERSON ( the NORP unicameral parliament ) were elected from the single - seat constituencies by simple plurality ( “ first past the post ” ) ( see GPE v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALVI ) and another CARDINAL seats were reserved for candidates from party lists ( see PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , ECHR CARDINALX ) .

CARDINAL . In accordance with section CARDINAL of the LAW , the system of electoral commissions included the ORG , commissions of electoral constituencies and electoral divisions . Each electoral constituency consisted of several divisions .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Act provided that the candidates for election were entitled to challenge the decisions , actions and omissions of the electoral commissions before the higher electoral commissions or the courts . The higher electoral commission , following such an application , the decision of the court or of its own motion , could set aside the decision of the lower commission and either take a new decision or oblige the commission concerned to reconsider the matter . Decisions , actions and omissions of the ORG could be challenged before ORG .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the Act determined the procedure for having the vote in an electoral division declared invalid by the electoral commission of that division .
Paragraph CARDINAL of this section stipulated :

“ An electoral commission of a division may declare the vote in the division invalid in the event of a breach of this LAW making it impossible to establish the results of the expression of the electorate ’s wishes . The electoral commission of a division may declare the vote invalid only in the following circumstances :

CARDINAL . NORP if actual unlawful voting has been established ( depositing of a ballot in the ballot box by a person other than the one to whom it has been issued ; voting by persons who have no right to vote ; voting by persons who are not included in the electoral lists of the relevant electoral division or by persons who have been wrongly included in the lists ; multiple voting by one voter ) if the number of fraudulent votes exceeds PERCENT of the total votes cast ;

CARDINAL . NORP if a ballot box has been damaged or destroyed so that it is impossible to establish the content of the ballots deposited , and if the number of damaged ballots exceeds PERCENT of the total votes cast ;
CARDINAL . NORP if the number of ballots deposited exceeds the number of voters who voted by PERCENT or more . ”
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the LAW regulated the procedure for examination by the constituency commissions of voting records issued by the division commissions .
Paragraph CARDINAL of this section provided :

“ If the electoral commission of a constituency establishes the existence of the circumstances enumerated in paragraph CARDINAL of section CARDINAL or of other circumstances which make it impossible to establish the wishes of the voters in the division , it may declare the vote in the division concerned invalid . ”

CARDINAL . The DATE LAW ( as amended on DATE ) provides for proportional representation in elections . LAW retains the power for commissions of electoral divisions to declare a ballot inadmissible if the number of fraudulent votes exceeds PERCENT of the total votes cast . Section CARDINAL provides that , after a recount , commissions of electoral constituencies are entitled to annul the vote in an electoral division if the circumstances set out in CARDINAL have been established , or if intentional acts have wrongfully interfered with the work of the members of the electoral commissions or the candidates’ observers .
